Signature is the act whereby a State expresses its consent to the text of a treaty but not necessarily its consent to be bound by its provisions. Once a State has signed a treaty it is not obliged to ratify it. However, the Australian government's policy is not to sign a treaty without the intention to ratify it at a later date. Ratification is confirmation of signature and signifies the intention to be bound by the provisions of a treaty. Accession is a single act whereby a State expresses its consent to be bound, instead of signature followed by ratification. Accession is only used in the case of multilateral agreements, usually when the agreement has been previously signed by other States.
